entry.title: Quickly look up a word or phrase from commandline
entry.content:
I wrote two very short Bash functions to help me quickly look up a word or phrase using elinks. You can use w3m as you wish but elinks shows a better layout in my eyes.

```bash

look up on urbandictionary.com

ub () { a=$@ elinks www.urbandictionary.com/${a// /%20} }

look up on thefreedictionary.com

fd () { a=$@ elinks www.thefreedictionary.com/${a// /+} } ```

Usage:

ub your_word
fd your_word

entry.title: MC (Midnight-Commander) 4.8.5 is slow, try 4.8.6
entry.content: Recently MC was upgraded from 4.7.x to 4.8.5 on my 32bit Fedora 17. The start-up time was totally unbearable, around 15 sec to start. I compiled the latest release v4.8.6 and that time dropped to the negligible (< 1sec).

entry.title: How to show GNOME top panel from keyboard?
entry.content:
My computer display is not big so I have tried ways to save my screen real-estate. It looks to me that the designers of GNOME 3 must have a huge display.  The default window title bar are too high in my view. Besides the top panel is thicker than that in Unity. To make my life easier, I first installed the GTK+ 3.x theme from gnome-look.org to reduce the height of the title bar. Then I set the top panel of GNOME desktop to 'auto hide'. But whenever I want to look at the weather or the time I have to move mouse over it to make it show. This is tedious. I searched online for a shortcut to show it. Many of results are prior to GNOME 3. Besides, I don't like the methods to change the 'gsetting' or 'gconf'.

It turns out that the simplest way to to hit 'Alt+F1' to activate the 'Application' in the top panel and hit 'Esc' to hide it again. So simple.

BTW: I'm using the fallback of GNOME 3.

entry.title: Fix the broken Bash file and directory name completion on Ubuntu Linux
entry.content: I didn't remember ever since when my Bash filename and directory name completion functioned wackily. Everytime I hit 'tab' to complete a directory name, Bash didn't append the backslash nor printed out candidates (just like what it described like here and here). It drove me banana. Meanwhile, my Bash worked very well under other Linux distributions (openSUSE, CentOS). The culprit was the a Bash completion file for adobe acrobat reader under /etc/bash_completion.d/. Delete it and the problem will be solved.

entry.title: Switch your Linux laptop display to a projector
entry.content:
In a job interview two months ago, no matter how hard I tried I simply couldn't export the screen of my laptop running Ubuntu Linux to a projector. It was the first time that I linked a Linux computer to a projector. Luckily the interviewers were generous enough and the four people of us sat together tightly to watch the slides on my 15" laptop screen. They gave me a job offer in the end but I just hoped that I could have done a better presentation that day.

I searched for a solution for that on the web. It seemed a headache for many Linux users. Finally I ran into Disper. It solved my problem perfectly.

Read on how to do it in more details here
